posts.name: Tom Line
posts.cooked:
After we climb, we would like to lock out motor sets in the motor subsystems from actuating to prevent the driver or operator from inadvertently hitting a button and breaking something.  What is the most elegant way of doing this?

It seems like the easiest place to put this code is in the motor sets in each subsystem.  We could use a setter method to set a flag in each subsystem that we have completed our climb.  That would require our climb command to own every subsystem.

Is it possible to have the other subsystems get a boolean that is only set in the climb subsystem?

What’s the best way to handle this?  I’d hate to have to put the code in every command we have that checks if we climbed.

posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
posts.cooked: Would scheduling a command that does nothing and cannot be interrupted by another command for the subsystem work?

posts.name: Tom Line
posts.cooked: Hm.  Hadn’t even thought about it.  We haven’t done un-interuptable commands.  It’s a hack, but it’s fairly simple.

posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
posts.cooked: Maybe the emergency override is press a couple of buttons at the same time and debounce them for 2 seconds.

posts.name: SCarp
posts.cooked:
Perhaps you could have a global state for the robot itself. i.e. once climbed you have some overall state that is ‘post-climb’. Your subsystems could check the overall robot state instead of having climb command own every subsystem (like you mentioned).

Then, in the climb subsystem could have ‘if robotState == postClimb; then: don’t send outputs, etc.’

posts.name: Tom Line
posts.cooked: Nah - once we’re up, we’re up.  We have one time latches on the climber.  Just making sure no one can move anything once we’re up is good enough.

posts.name: Tom Line
posts.cooked: Would this be similar to setting a variable in teleop periodic and reading that in the subsystems?

posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
posts.cooked: Ahh - the real requirement and a trivial solution System.exit(0);

posts.name: Tim Winters
posts.cooked:
There are a few ways to prevent the robot from doing anything in code. Here’s two examples

But also just putting the controller down should prevent anything from happening

posts.name: SCarp
posts.cooked:
I’d try something like this…

Create static variable to hold robot state:

Set robotState in Climber subsystem

Use robotState in other subsystems

But if you truly want to stop all commands; @ArchdukeTim suggestion makes sense.

posts.name: Tom Line
posts.cooked: Yeah, I like this better.  We already have constants for each subsystem that we can use to disable motors when trouble shooting.  This is a natural extension of that.
